awd_titl_txt: Application of Year of Polar Prediction- Southern Hemisphere (YOPP-SH) Observations for Improvement of Antarctic Numerical Weather Prediction
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will take advantage of the greater number of Antarctic weather observations collected as part of the World Meteorological Organization's "Year of Polar Prediction". Researchers will use these additional observations to study new ways of incorporating data into existing weather prediction models. The primary goal of this research is to improve the accuracy of weather forecasts in Antarctica. This work is important, as the harsh weather in Antarctica greatly impacts scientific research and the support of this research. Being able to accurately predict changing weather increases the safety and efficiency of Antarctic field science and operations.  

The proposed effort seeks to advance goals of the World Meteorological Organization's Polar Prediction Project and its Year of Polar Prediction-Southern Hemisphere (YOPP-SH) effort. Researchers will investigate and demonstrate the forecast impact of enhanced atmospheric observations obtained from YOPP-SH's Special Observing Period on polar numerical weather prediction. This will be done by using the Antarctic Mesoscale Prediction System (AMPS). AMPS is the primary numerical weather prediction capability for the United States Antarctic Program (USAP). Modeling experimentation will assess the impact of Special Observing Period data on Antarctic forecasts and will serve as a vehicle for testing new data assimilation approaches for AMPS. The primary goal for this work is improved forecasting and numerical weather prediction tools. Outcomes will include quantification of the value of enhanced southern hemisphere atmospheric observations. This work will also help improve AMPS and its ability to support the USAP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the forecast impact on Antarctic numerical weather prediction of enhanced atmospheric observations obtained via the World Meteorological Organization's Year of Polar Prediction in the Southern Hemisphere (YOPP-SH). This was done for the benefit of weather analysis and prediction for all Antarctic science and operations using the framework of the Antarctic Mesoscale Prediction System (AMPS); AMPS is the key numerical weather prediction capability supporting the forecasters of the United States Antarctic Program as well as Antarctic meteorological research. The numerous additional radiosonde observations were acquired during YOPP-SH's summer Special Observing Period, running 16 November 2018-15 February 2019, when 17 countries came together for unprecedented efforts to advance the understanding and success of Antarctic weather prediction for the benefit of all Antarctic nations.

Substantial reductions in the forecast error (up to 10%) over Antarctica for up to 3 days ahead throughout the weather producing part of the atmosphere were found for temperature, followed by wind speed, and somewhat for relative humidity. The impact was confined to latitudes mostly over Antarctica while impacts farther north were significant but much more muted on average, consistent with the few additional YOPP-SH observations in that region. One important conclusion is that Antarctic forecasts especially in winter would be substantially improved by better coverage in space and time by radiosonde releases from the Antarctic interior. Further, it is probable that additional radiosonde ascents from middle latitudes would also be beneficial for improved Antarctic weather forecasts.

Advances in the AMPS weather prediction system also were achieved by the research. Better use of observations is now made to start the numerical weather forecasts. Experience by global weather forecasting centers has demonstrated that this so-called "data assimilation" has led to the biggest advances in model forecast skill. In addition, how several key processes are represented in the atmospheric forecast model have been substantially refined.
